bibl.title: Letter from Luther Ely Smith to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 12, 1942

div1.p: Smith congratulates Kean on receiving the Gorgas medal and recalls the day in December 1934 when the commission met in St. Louis and visited historical landmarks. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Luther Ely Smith to Jefferson Randolph Kean, November 12, 1942
div1.opener:
LUTHER ELY SMITH
LUTHER ELY SMITH, JR.
VICTOR B. HARRIS
HAROLD C. HANKE
CHARLES P. MULDOON
LUTHER ELY SMITH
ATTORNEY AND COUNSELOR
SUITE 1554 TELEPHONE BUILDING
ST. LOUIS, MO.
TELEPHONE
GARFIELD 0882
CABLE ADDRESS
“LESMITH”
Nov. 12, 1942.
General Jefferson Randolph Kean
2804 End St., N.W.,
Georgetown, Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I was delighted to read in the St. Louis Globe-Democrat
on Sunday an Associated Press dispatch from San Antonio, Texas,
giving an account of the award to you of the Gorgas Medal and $500
honorarium for distinguished service in preventive medicine in the
United States Armed Forces. You were noted as the founder of the
Medical Reserve Corps.

Since viewing the reproduction of the very fine mural in
Cleveland, and reading the brochure containing the address deliv-
ered on the occasion of the unveiling of the mural, we have felt
that through you we have a deep personal interest in the great bat-
tle which you and your associates fought in Cuba against yellow fev-
er. You were in the vanguard with Walter Reed, Agramonte and the others.

It is fine to have this recognition given to you. Mrs.
Smith and I both heartily congratulate you.
I hope Mrs. Kean and you are quite well.

Your ears should have burned last Saturday night when
Mrs. Crosby, widow of Colonel W. D. Crosby, inquired about
you, as she always does when I see her.

I wish you might be in St. Louis again to see the old
Court House, which has been completely rehabilitated as to its
exterior and a portion of the interior. A very fine national ex-
pansion museum in the southern portion of the Court House was opened
last month.

It seems a far cry back to that December day in 1934 when
The Commission met here, and we all went to the old Court House and
visited the room where the Dred Scott case was tried, and the rotun-
day where Senator Benton made his famous Pacific Railroad speech.

Nor shall we ever forget the very delightful guests we had
on that occasion - “Haec olim meminisse juvabit”. It is a lovely memory.

Mrs. Smith, I am sure, would join in sending her very best
love to each of you if she knew I were writing - as I do in my own
proper person.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Luther Ely Smith Luther Ely Smith
